body:
Should know the memory space for storing session datas. Core PHP provides
more memory than the Codeigniter. So you couldn't store more datas and
retrieve itself quickly.
That's why you get the different time delays !
On Jun 19, 2015 2:43 AM, "Tobias Boonstoppel" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Hi,
> 
> I am trying to use memcached as session and cache storage and running into
> troubles doing so.
> 
> For session setting userdata works for the 2 first requests, after that
> there are huge delays, up 20 sec, and I'm not sure where this comes from. I
> tested the same server setup without using codeigniter and it works fine:
> 
> ini_set('session.save_handler', 'memcached');
> ini_set('session.save_path', 'tcp://10.126.1.17:11211');
> 
> session_start();
> 
> $_SESSION['foo'] = 'bar';
> $_SESSION['time'] = time();
> 
> var_dump($_SESSION);
> 
> For cache there are no delays but the data is never stored. In the code
> below both var_dumps output bool(false):
> 
> public function test() {
> $this->load->driver('cache', array(
>     'adapter' => 'memcached',
>     'backup' => 'file'
> ));
> 
> var_dump($this->cache->get('foo'));
> $this->cache->save('foo', 'test test', 300);
> var_dump($this->cache->get('foo'));
> }
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/bcit-ci/CodeIgniter/issues/3919.

The session delays are caused by emulated locks that serve for avoiding concurrency issues ... don't worry about that - the delays will disappear once the writes start working again.  
That being said however, I'm afraid you'd have to debug this one on your own.

I'm not sure this comment belongs here, but the CI 3 documentation sample code for memcached doesn't work. The docs need to be updated to reflect the more complex driver loading that actually works.

http://www.codeigniter.com/userguide3/libraries/caching.html#memcached-caching

issue.title: Can not use memcached to store session.

repository.name: CodeIgniter
repository.description: Open Source PHP Framework (originally from EllisLab)

issue.body:
The file 'Session_memcached_driver.php', line 111,
$this->_memcached->getServerList()  Is empty.
PHP Version 5.4.41, memcached Version 2.2.0 .

body:
@sneakyimp & @narfbg 
         One very important and easy to miss thing... If you are using memcache then save_path must have the "tcp://" prefix, if you are using memcached then the save_path should not have the "tcp://" prefix.

issue.title: Fix PHP session_write_close warning when writing empty session to Redis

repository.name: CodeIgniter
repository.description: Open Source PHP Framework (originally from EllisLab)

issue.body:
I'm working on an application that will eventually save session data, but doesn't yet (other than for user logins).  Therefore, the session driver is loaded on each pageview but nothing is written to it.  I noticed that I was getting a `PHP warning: session_write_close(): Failed to write session data (user). Please verify that the current setting of session.save_path is correct ()`, and spent some time debugging.

It seems that if writing an empty session (that is, where `$session_data` is a blank string) to redis, the key isn't actually created in the redis store (expected redis behaviour, I guess).  Therefore, when the driver then runs the `setTimeout` function on that key, it returns 0, which triggers a failure in the `session_write_close` handler.

Therefore, my fix is to simply not set a timeout when the session fingerprint is equal to that of a blank session - as soon as some session data is added, the code runs as it originally did.

body:
I am using memcached for session handling and cache purposes. With the upgrade to CI 3.0.4, it starts to throw the following error (while it was working as expected on CI 3.0.3:

```
Unknown: Failed to write session data (user). Please verify that the current setting of session.save_path is correct (/var/lib/php5)
```

If I replace CI 3.0.4's `Session_memcached_driver.php` file with 3.0.3's `Session_memcached_driver.php` it is working again.

You're confusing "not showing an error" with "working", and in fact the video shows that ...

See that `<sessionId>:lock` key at the [58 second mark](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Skh1IpF4-vg&feature=youtu.be&t=58)? If it actually worked, you'd have one more without the ':lock' suffix.

As I said, the only difference is that 3.0.4 actually tells you that something's wrong.
So the question is, which line returns `$this->_failure` for you? You'll have to do some debugging ...
So I proved that you are right :smile: I'll try to dig more..

@narfbg, @yahyaerturan

I have taken the codeigniter version 3.0.3 and 3.0.4 for testing this error.. I used xdebug with netbeans editor.

I noticed that, $this->_success and $this->_failure variables introduced in the 3.0.04 version.

In the write function of session_memcached_driver.php, the line no 198 is a return statement which returns $this->_failure; This is where the problem starts.

If you change this variable from $this->_failure to FALSE, then it is perfectly working in v3.0.04 also without any error(Unknown: Failed to write session data (user). Please verify that the current setting of session...)

If my fix is correct, then guide me how to commit it.

@cmeenatchisundaram Not correct ... you're doing the same thing @yahyaerturan did - thinking that the error message itself is the problem and trying to hide it. That doesn't solve anything.

Line 198 returning failure means that you were unable to obtain a lock. If you're running PHP7, this should fix the issue: c4de3c2f93cb6d2af65b325ae2812fccad7e98b8 (given that the lock was actually acquired, but falsely reported in your case)

Edit:

Can any of you verify what [Memcached::touch()](https://secure.php.net/manual/en/memcached.touch.php) returns (and the getResultCode() value) when used on a key that doesn't exist yet?
